DIV1.HEAD: To the knowing Reader.
DIV1.P: A Good Reader, helps to make a Book; a bad injuries it: The Author of this, had no mind to be a man in Print; nor tooke he any care for a Sculpture, to illustrate the Frontis-piece by crowning himselfe with Laurel: Neither did he write his owne Encomiums, and (to prejudicate the simple) say his friends forc'd them upon him; they may help to sell the Book, not better the Mat∣ter. And since this Tragedy is come to tell its own tale, and to speak for it self, he wil he glad to know it able to cary its own commendation; And (being an Infant, newly deliver'd to the world from the wombe of the Press) he hopes the knowing Rea∣der will rather Crown it by his Candor, then kill it in the Cradle.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Right Honourable, Mountague Berty, Earle of Lindsey, Lord Willougbby to Eresby &c.
DIV1.P: YOu are no stranger to things of this nature, and therefore the Dedication will not startle you; such there are (my Lord) whose soules are confin'd to their Chinck, and these looke squint-ey'd upon a Dedication, because they feare there is a Spirit in't will separate them: But my Lord, your Noblenesse to learning, and wit raiseth your estimate to so high an accompt among knowing men, thi from thence I have derived this bold∣nesse, which I hope is pardonable not onely for that your justice calls upon me for a duty I long since owed your Ho∣nour, but also in regard the Thing presented is no sleight Piece, but such (my Lord) at I presume will accord with your judgement and likeing: It past the Stage with gene∣rall Applause (my selfe being the last that that Acted Ma∣tilda in it) and since through the absurdity of times, it hath laine obscured. My Lord, though it doth not appeare in it's ancient and full glory, yet it comes drest; first, with an humble regard to your Honour, and then a confidence of it's naked worth, but both it and my selfe, are willingly subjected unto your Honours sentence, which I hope will not be too heavy, especially upon

DIV1.HEAD: Actus 1. Scoena 1.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: THey will not come?

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: They will not.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: They had been better—
What was their answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Thus said Fitzwater, father of the faction,
That was Generall for the Barrons against your Majestie:
Tell John,

SP.SPEAKER: Ki.
SP.L: John!

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: That was his Epithite;
(Alledging how you stood at Rome, put from
Your Kingly office.) Tell John, quoth he, (and frown'd)
That here at Baynards Castle, we intend
A settled stay for private reformations.
Of conceiv'd injuries, which by the peace
The King made with us, were not throughly search'd,
But like green wounds, clos'd with too swift a salve,
(Upon your private ends) are with more danger
Doubts and distracted difficulties again
Broke forth; but having drawn them to a head,
They would send them to you to be ratified,
And then give their attendance.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: This is brave;
Who was there else?

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Richmond, imperious Leister, and old Bruce.
(The second in this revolt,) who sent the same return.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Anest of Rebels; to try the truth of these fine florishes,
You with Lord Mowbray, post unto Guilford,
And being there, (pretending a visite unto Bruces Lady,)
Wind into observation of the Castle so from her,
(The engine upon which these factions move,)
Discover the intent of their disignes.

SP.SPEAKER: Queen.
SP.L: Sure sir, the Lady is noble; but your Majesties
Injunction shall be obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: This not onely advantages
Our meeting with Fitzwaters Daughter,
(O how the thought) startles my blood)
But likewise furthers our resolv'd proceedings:
Chester the news?

SP.SPEAKER: Chest.
SP.L: Conceal your selfe sir,
I have trapt her with a snare.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Agen, then I shall see he—

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: You told me Chester
That the Queen did earnestly request my attendance:
You said she was here i'th Garden,
But it seems you were mis-inform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Excellent innocence how art thou trapt!
I must attend the King; please you walk Madam
But towards the Grove, I was told the Queen and Ladies
Retyred there for shade.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I shall,

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: And I must vanish

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh heaven, the King!

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Thy friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: False Chester!

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Fair Matilda,
Mistresse of youth and beauty, sweet as a spring,
And comely as the holy shining Priest
Deckt in his glorious sacerdotall vestment;
Yet heare the passions of a love sick Prince,
And crown thy too too cruell heart with pitty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Yet let fall your too too passionate pleaings,
And crown your royall heart with excellent reason.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: The Queen will heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Speak but a word that—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: That may sound like something,
That may but busie my strong labouring heart,
With hope that thou wilt grant, and every morning
I will walk forth and watch the early Lark,
And at her sweetest note I will protest,
Matilda spake a word was like that note.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh how you tempt: remember pray your vows
To my betroth'd Earl Robert Huntington;
Did you not wish just as the poyson toucht
His manly heart, i ever you again
Laid battery to the fair fort of my unvanquish'd
Vertue, your death might be like his untimely,
And be poyson'd. Oh take heed sir,
Saints stand upon heavens silver battlements,
When Kings make vows, and lay their
Listening ears to Princes Protestations.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: So did Matilda swear to live and die a maid,
At which fair Nature like a Snail shrunck back,
As loath to hear from one so fair, so foul
A wound: my vow was vain, made without
Recollection of my reason; and yours, Oh madnesse!
Maids have sure forsworne such vowes:
For Huntington, he like a heap of summers
Dust into his Grave is swept; and bad vows
Still are better broke then kept.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Alas great sir, your Queen you cannot make me;
What is it then instructs your tongue? Oh sir!
In things not right,
Lust is but loves well languag'd hypocrite.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Words shall convert to deeds then; I am the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Doe but touch me,
And as I graspe steel in my trembling hand,
SP.STAGE: Offers violence, she drawes a knife.
SP.L: So sure the King shall see Matilda fall
A sacrifice to vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Cruell Maid,
Crueller then the Kid that eanes her young
On the rough bosome of a ragged flint:
Go get thee to the woods, for thou art wild
As flame, or winter; where so e're thou walk'st
May wild winds chide thee, and the reeling Trees
Like a confus'd fall of many waters
Rail on thy rudeness; may the birds that build
Among the wanton branches, stead of teaching
Notes to their young, sing something like thy niceness:
And lastly, may the Brooks when thou shalt lie
And cast a pair of cruell busie eyes
Upon their subtill slydings, may the water,
The troubled image of my passions war
With the stones, the matter of thy heart, that thou maist learn
Thy hardnesse and my sufferings to discern;
And so whilst I (if it be possible) study to forget you,
May beasts, and bird, and brooks, and trees, and wind,
Hear me, and call Matilda too unkind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Ile unto Baynards Castle to my father,
Oh she had a violent need of Castles, where a King
Layes such violent seige; but Oh truth,
Thou art (whilst tenant in a noble brest,)
A crown of Christall in an Ivory chest.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Shall I be dazled with effeminate darings?

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: With a womans ward, a knife too.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Here I left her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.L: But here she is not now sir.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Oh Chester run, run as thou lov'st my peace,
Feather thy feet with lovers wishes, let but my desires
Dwel in thy eyes, thou'lt find her, were she compast
With a Cimerian mist.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.L: I will do my best sir.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Thy best; do every thing, do any thing,
Do all things that may find her; whether Love
Leads thy dark Labyrinth; cannot Kings be free
From thy impetuous buffets? I have de'd
A heardned heart, obdurate to thy shafts,
And some times am so, when in the very minute
Calling to mind Matilda's tears, like drops
Continued upon marble, they pierce through,
And I am soft again. Hast found her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.L: No sir, she is by this in Baynards Castle,
Where her Father and the Lords—

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Command our Barge, wee'l after her like lightning:
We must have pledges Chester for their faiths; if they refuse,
Thunder shall meet with thunder, and each eye
Shall see strange Comets in this troubled skie.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Fitzwater, old Bruise, young Bruise, Richmond and Leister, as in Baynards Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: My noble Lords, and honourable friends,
Not to particularlize (what need plain dealing
Be apparelled in particulars?) to a short supper,
Or a poor pittance rather, ye are all
Heartily welcome, very heartily, I must tell truth still.

SP.SPEAKER: O Br.
SP.L: Brother we thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eitz.
SP.L: I would we had my sister your wife, at Guilford with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Where are the Ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Comfoting Matilda, sad return'd from Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Betraid by Chester, and again escap'd
Like a chaste Dove out of the fowlers Net,
The lustfull King.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Oh John, John, wilt thou never
Leave thy wags tricks? but let it passe, tis best
Because indeed tis past.

SP.SPEAKER: Leís.
SP.L: I wonder how he receiv'd our resolv'd answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Bu.
SP.L: No matter how, he's like to have no other;
Now by my blood, you vext my very soul
That you snt any.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: Sonne, have a tamer spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Bru.
SP.L: Yes, and like horses,
Be held by'th nose by frivilous respect,
Whilst he casts Copperis into our sores, and searches
Past honours patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Nephew, Nephew, hear me,
Lets bear a little; faith he is the King,
And though at Rome he does stand interdicted,
Yet now and then takes a good start or two
Towards regularity, till the fit comes on him;
And for your neat horse simile observe me,
Richmond and you are young men, we three old,
But not too old to tell truth; the horse that will not
Stand till and endure searching, how e're in summer
With warmth and pasture, he may strike at flies,
And play the wanton in a wealthy meadow,
For all his summer pastime, yet tis said,
Winter will leave him but a lean scal'd jade;
Come, come, y'ar fooles, y'ar fooles.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Well let us—bear then.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Bru.
SP.L: et us? Oh my blood!
Besides, our in uries in his breach of promise,
He made by stains and publique grievances,
How in the flames of his adulterate heart
Pursues he my chaste Cousin, by flights gets her
Within his tallon, and but this afternoon,
(Had not her friendly knife enfranchis'd her)
Even in the face of heven, in his own Garden
He would have ravish'd her.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: Broher, we are bound in honour not to bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Let him know our griefs, and if—

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Well, well, with iss and ands
Mad men leave Rocks, and leap into the Sands;
But something shall be thought on.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich
SP.L: The King attended
Onely with the Earle of Chester, Oxford, and some
Other Gentlement, is new landed on the Stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.L: The King!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Bru.
SP.L: Shut the stairs Gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Twere better Gate and stairs
Were floating through bridg; we are safe my cholerick cousin,
As in a Sanctuary; tis enough
(A man would think,) to see a great Prince thus,
Cause wee'd not go to him, to come to us,
SP.STAGE: Ent. King, Oxford, Chester. and other Lords
SP.L: Indeed, indeed, you speak unkindly.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Behold great Lords,
The Cedars of the Kingdome, how the King
(A shrub) shrincks out of majestie.
And comes to you; here's a fine Conventicle,
Are ye blowing up new sires? and must Fitzwaters
(Plain-breasted as his unaffected habite,)
Be Generall again, again be call'd
The Marshall of Heavens Army and the Churches?
Are you Planet st uck you cannot talke.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Your pardon sir,
I led the Barrons, but twas when they could not choose
But choose a leader, and then me they chose;
And why so think ye? they all lov'd your Grace,
And grieve, grieve very heartily, I tell you,
To see you by some state mice so misled:
This state mice that nibble so upon the Lands impaired freedom
That would not so play in the Lyons eare,
But that by tickling him themselves to advantage;
This troubl'd us, and griev'd the body Politique,
And this we sought to mend; I tell truth John, I,
We are thy friends John, and if ye take from friendship
The liberty of modest admonition,
Ye leave no mark whereby to distinguish it
From the fawning passion of a Dog-base flattery;
If I speak plain, this truth be my desence,
A good mans comsort is his Conscience:
And so much for plain Robin.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Fitzwater, Bruce, Richmond, and stubborn Leister,
This is the last of our admonitions,
Either lay by those Arms, those lawlesse arms,
Which you have listed 'gainst your Lord the King,
And give such pledges as we shall accept
For settling of your loyalties, or here
By the abused sufferings of a King,
And by the unkind scars with which you have
Deform'd the face of England; misery
Shall over take you in a shape shall fright
The Iron heart of faction, and the King
Shall come no more acquainted with compassion,
But call the bloodiest ends a righteous vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: I will not leave mine arms,
Nor break my word to you,
Unlesse provok'd, and justly; you have my faith,
If you mislike that pledge—

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: We do.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: And I reply that I can spare no nother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: D'ce hear sir?

SP.SPEAKER: O Bru.
SP.L: Already we have pawn'd the now scorn'd gage
Of our afflicted honours, which refus'd
Flies back again, and so we stand discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: King John, King John,
Perform but the seal'd Covenants you are fled from,
The Charter running thus, given by our hand
The seventeenth day of June, and in the year
215 (the whole Realm being sworn to't,)
And six and twenty Peers and Barrons sworn
To the execution (who if you fail) are perjur'd
Do this, and like a plat of Osier wands
We shall bow any way, and you shall work us
Into what fashion you shall fancy; but
if you be melancholly, love-sick John,
Or Lyon, unyoak'd Heifer, head-strong John,
(As in the matter of the Losse of Normandie,
When Anjou, Brittain, Main, Poictou, and Turwin,
Were deliver'd up to Philip) you'l find your friends
Not facile Willowes, but abrupt brambles,
Whose intricate irregularity
Whilst you shall go about to rectifie,
They'l prick your fingers, and with unkind scratches,
Expose you to a late deplor'd experience:
Come, come, know this, when love in our side sings,
The unkindest wounds are those we take from Kings;
I am plain Robin.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: A down right Rebell.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Rebell!

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: So are ye all.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.L: Rebells!

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Traytors.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.L: Traytors!

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Rebels and Traytors; Chester, Oxford, Gentlemen,
Stand on your guards, there's danger in the room.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: You ate too passionate, perform with us,
You shall walk over us, if not, we stand
Our injur'd Countries Justicers.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Proud boaster.
This night shall raise a storme: Brav'd? with you Bruce
We will begin; and yet he is the Brother
Unto Matilda's Father, but his insolence,
Oh love; a little while let revenge raigne,
This night shall beget passages shall prove
Your King a Lyon (vext) as (pleas'd) a Dove.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Lights for the King; there Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: What will you do? a tempest curl'd his forehead
Into the fashion of an angry Ocean,
Made wild with winds.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: We must resolve on something.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: And suddenly, for in his executions
He is swift as lightning, ayr is not more light.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Pandulph the Popes stern Legate, tis divulg'd,
Is againe come over from the Pope, to proffer
The King his readmission into the Church,
And take off his six years interdiction
Upon some propositions yet conceal'd,
And this may busie the King yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: This? the Greyhound
Is not more eager at his flying game,
Then I know King John is in his passions
Gf love or anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: Why Brother, is this a time to study?

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Troth I was thinking of—stay, stay, I hav't,
I was thinking brother Bruce,—now tis gone again,
And farewell it, lets ply our businesse now:
If you mark't, he said he would begin with you;
I Would have you to night (stay not for the Sun,
Which sure will rise blushing at this nights brawling)
Do you and Richmond, with some score of men
Post to your house, tis but an hours riding,
And something more; there fortifie your selves,
Your Ladie, and your pretty little Sonnne,
Poor knave he dreams not of these Thunderbolts:
You my young mad cap, with your Cuz my daughter,
Shall unto Hartford Castle, she is the brand
I feare will fire our Troy; Leister and I
Will gather Powers, and thither after you;
You two for Guilford, you two for Hartford,
And we two, wheither wast we two must go?

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Go? we two must stay i'th City.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Passion of me, where was my memory;
But come, come, when Kings our Dials retrograde do run,
We leave to look on them, and go by'th Sun:
Lights, lights, good Gentlemen:

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Queene, Lady, Bruce, and Hubert.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Good Lady take not on so, Oxford sayes all
Is very well at London.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Yes, very well;
Why then follow'd he your Grace with a Troop of horse,
A band of men? why hath he seizd the Castle,
Cashierd my Servants? Oh Madam can it be,
Your Grace (the Alter where I ever paid
A Subjects devout Love,) should by a slight,
a fained accidentall visite make,
An entrance for hostility and terror.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Hubert, redeem you in this Ladies faith,
And relate the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Only upon mine honour
Was I sent to seize this Ladies young Son George,
As a pledge to'th King for her Lords loyalty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: No Hubert, my Son is far enough from thee,
Thou fatall keeper of poor Boys.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: You mean
Concerning Arthur, the unfortunate Sonne
Of Jeffery Plantaganet; Oh mad rumour!
Who would trust thee but with so much reputation
An honest begger boasts of?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.L: In that beleeve me Madam, report hath wronged him,
Which I can witnesse Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: The King come to,
Oh my sweet George, my joy; what wilt thou do?

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: All is to our desire; where's Bruces Sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Convey'd to Wales she affirms Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Where thou shalt never see him John.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Good Madam,
Wee'l speak with you anon, Queene Isabell,
Thou must be still an agent to secure
Me and my Kingdome, straight with the Earl of Chester;
Post thou to Hartford Castle, whither we are certifi'd
Young Bruce is fled with old Fitzwaters daughter,
Try if by fair means thou canst win her to
Attend on thee at Court; if we have not her
A pledge, (as this) for her Fathers faith, we stand
The food of faction, get her any way;
If she deny, Chester with forces ready,
Of from the Castle, shall give them fierce assault,
And force them past entreaties; go my love
And play the Amazon, with her surprisall,
Secure a Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: This craves hast and care; come noble Chester
You shall along; but good my Lord forget not
That Ladies kindnesse to me.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Oh my sweet.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: What a fine thing he makes the Queen; Oh lust,
With what smooth craft thou creeptst to things unjust.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Oh my Matilda, if power or policy
may get thee once more in these arms, I will hazard
Even to a Kingdom for thee; come Madam fear not
I wear no frowns, I am all mirth, lets see your pretty Son.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I fear your mirth is like the Porpoist pastimes,
My Son hath been in Wales this moneth.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Hubert, see the Gates lock'd, a guard upon the Walls,
Whilst we take some to search.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Where will you search King John?
For heavens sake do not search.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Nay and't be come to that.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Let me go,
In these proceedings the Kings safety rests,
The Lyon must not bend to baser breasts.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Heaven to thee I kneel, who affrighted Mother am,
Oh from this Lyons claws keep my poor Lambe.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter old Bruce, and Richmond, and above Oxford.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: The Castle Gates are shut, swift footed Tyranie,
That canst when thou pursu'st thy wild desires,
Out run the wantan Roe; Oh Richmond, Richmond,
I fear our stay all night, ha's made me witness
Of a day darker then night.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Yonr fears and your afflictions
Meet in one Center, for it seems the King
Sent Oxford in the night on the walls;
Behold where Oxford stands, I fear they have seiz'd
Your Sonne, your Wife and Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: Oxford, thou signe
Set up to shew me where my sorrows dwell,
Martyr me not with circumstances; but tell me,
Is it (as from thy ominous presence there)
We may conjecture.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Because you request brevity,
Then by my ominous presence here great Lords
You conjecture that you come too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Let force our entrance,
We have tweuty men of spirit to dare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: A score of Cowards, Oxford,
Dar'st thou be honourable?

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: An other time,
But now I have no leisure, the King is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: In person.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Yes, and power;
And if the Queen and Chester speed as the King has,
We shall have a pledget too for Fitzwaters loyalty,
And so good day, ye meet the proverb here,
Ye both are early up but near the neare.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: We strongly may conclude from their intelligence
Of your Son, and fair Matilda's flight to Hartford,
Thither the Queen and Chester are repair'd,
Either by force or policy to obtaine her,
So that the nearest path to our proceedings.
Is to post back to London, and to hasten
Her Father thither with his powers, and so
Secure your Sonne, his Daughter, and it may be,
Surprise the Queen and Chester.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: If we do,
If but a hair of my betrayed wife,
Or my poor boy do perish, a head royall
Shall be sent back, slight scratches leave no scars
But deep wounds are seeds of Civill wars.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus 2. Scoena 1.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter King, Hubert, Lady, and Bruce.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: YOu would not then produce him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Think of it Madam,
And for your own discharge, give up your Son.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I have him not to give.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: We will no more be mock'd, are all the people,
SP.STAGE: Enter 2 Souldiers with a Hamper, the Boy in it.
SP.L: Horses, and Cattel voided forth the Castle?

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: All but this Hamper which stood underneath
The stairs that led into the Dungeon.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: A place suspicious, search it.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Let not rudenesse boast sir,
She was born i'th presence of a Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Tis lock'd my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Where is the Key?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I know not, lost.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Cut it open.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Do not, do not, indeed you'l spoile it then.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Well then they shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Now the King is gracious.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.P: But fetch each man a Torch, and here before me Set it a fire.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Oh rather cut it sir in a thousand peeces;
Why did you tell me that they should not cut it,
And now would burn it? who did teach you sir
To mock a wounded heart? look, look, and they do not go
To cut it too; good sir, I have a Jewel
Lyes conceal'd there, which I hid for feare o'th souldiers,
Of infinite value.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Tis open my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: what's in't?

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.P: Marry youth in a basket sir, here is the prety Jewel Of infinite value.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Hold him fast fellow, Hubert keepe back the mother.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I would be kept back, is that a Boy
To crush with a rude hand, alas a grisle
Look, and his very looks do not fright my Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Oh mother here is a man lookes very black,
(Pray do not hurt me) indeed, and if you doe,
You'l make my mother cry

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: For heavens sakellet me kisse him, I warrant you the Childe was almost smotherd, come from him George.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: A wo'not let me go, if I were your match,
Ide give you a good sound box o'th eare,

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Come, Come, 'we will not part you, Hubert there waits
One Brand without, servant to the Earle of Chester,
With a guard, let him Convey them both to Winsor Castle,
And by this signet to sir Walter Blunt,
Deteyne them in his custody, untill
We shall direct him further.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Oh brave, mother I have heard of Wiusor Castle, my father
Told me there are brave bowes and arrowes; and drums there.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Oh happy Innocent, who in spight of foes
Can play the pretty wanton with thy woes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: The Lord Steward sir
Is come it seemes from London.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: My Lord of Winchester the meaning of your speed?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: The Popes legate Sir,
The Cardinal Pandulp is ariv'd at London,

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: What newes with him; Six yeares we have stood
An intedicted man, can he bring lowder thunder?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: He brings proffers of peace sir,
Advantagable peace too, if that you please
To make a resignation of your Crowne:

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Good sir suffer mee,
And that to him to the Popes use; withall;
(Paying an Annuall tribute for your Kingdomes
Of England, and of Ircland, in the presence
Of the whole body of the Peers,) he has power
From his Holiness to reinvest your temples
With the rich Diadem; and with all pronounce you
Again admitted into the Church, your power
Weakned and wounded, yet may by this meanes
Lyon like, rowse it selfe and remove all obstacles
Twixt you and the high calling of a King,
Which by the reason you stood Curst at Rome,
Receiv'd affronts so frequent; besides Fitzwaters,
With Leister (who by the return of Bruce and Richmand
From thence to London, were upon expedition,
With there powers for Hartford Castle to intercept
The proceedings of the Queen and Chester;)
I have staid upon the Legats special chardge
To attend your resignation, potent nessesity
(The great dispenser with all Cerimony,)
Calls it a point of Policy, whereby
You build your selfe, ruine your enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: And then you stand again, sir a King absolute
And dazel faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Ki.
SP.L: Come we will catch craft
With imitation, he that would screw his ends
To his own aims, must mingle (when he wins)
Secret dissemblings 'mongst his venial sinnes.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Souldiers, and young Bruce prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: You are mine Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Tis false, I am Fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: This day to fortune then I sacrifice,
As to my Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Br.
SP.L: A Whore is then your Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: A Whore!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: A rascall Jade,
That takes with the dixterity she gives; tell me
Of your Mistresse and the Devil: Oh my stars.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: O sir we have wayes to tame you, you remember
You brav'd me in the presence of the King,
At Baynards Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Oh I am mad,
Yet not so mad, but I dare still brave Chester,
And from the top of my affliction,
Upon thy light heel'd Mrs. wanton fortune,
Cast from the manly temper of my blood
A noble scorn.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.L: You shall be fetter'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Fetter'd:

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.L: Yes, and sent
Up to the King as an arch Rebel, to whom,
To whom (before) we have by Letters sent our happy fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Rebell:
By that boyling sea of blood which thou hast troubl'd,
Had my desires but bodies, I would burst
Fetters of steele, tear off thy canker'd flesh,
And with thy Jaw-bone, (thou honour wounding man)
I would kill a thousand of these Rascals.

SP.SPEAKER: Ch.
SP.L: Drag him
Into the Castle, since your fortunes move you,
We'l force you to a madnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Fool thou canst not;
Frost makes fire fervent, he that wisely knows
His wealthy fate, bravely becomes his woes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Are you so arm'd, away with him.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter the Queene, dragging in Matilda, her hair loose, and Face bloody.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Come forward furie, witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Alas, why thus
Great Queen do you mis-use me? credite me
I do not feare to die, young Infants do it;
Nor wish I life, the murtherer enjoyes it;
But let me know my trespasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: I'me made your stale,
The King, the King your strumpet; oh thou wretch,
The matter my spleen!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hear me but speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Yes, I will thee speak,
That every syllable may serve instead
Of a fierce wind to blow my fiercer fury
Into the fashion of a punishmen,
Fitting the daring of thy trespasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Heare me;
By these red marks, registers of your rashnesse,
And by these tears, the fruits of my affliction,
That the King passionately pursues my love,
Is truth uncontrdicted; but if I
Did ever think you wrong, let mine honour be
buried in dark oblivion.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Sin's a sweet tame Serpent, they must beguile
Cloath rude errors, in a soft smooth stile:
ut strmpst thou shalt ruin't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Shift for your selfe Madam,
Richmond escap'd from London with the powers
Leavied by Leister, and Fitzwater, (who
Were stai'd by Winchester, and the Legate Pandulph)
Hath rescued Bruce, got again the Castle,
SP.STAGE: Ent. Y. Bruce, and Richmond with Souldiers.
SP.L: And make you now their search.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Cease on the Queen;
Madam you are our prisoner,

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Keep Chester safe good Ricmond;
Ha! oh what rude hand
Hath ras'd this Book of beauty? a face where vertue
Intelligibly stood to charm the Reader: Tell me Cozen,
And by the thousands of thy tears, and fears
No tittle, place, degree, the very Grave
Shall not secure the offender.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: There is death in's angry eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat
SP.L: The rude Souldiers
My noble Cozen hail'd me thus, and tore me,
And would have sure done worse, but that the Queen,
The wondrou kind Queen in her royall person,
Came with a troop of well appointed Souldiers,
and rescued me.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: She mocks me sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: The Queen so kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: O Cousin had you seen
How good she was in her quick speed, how zealous
To relieve innocence, you would have thought
She'd kil'd them with her frowns e're she came at them,
So lamentably miserable were my sufferings,
So excellently noble was her charity.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Now by my life, 'twas honour in the highest,
Because a foe, and gracious Madam, not
To be out bid in this brave Mart of honour,
You shall have a safe Convoy, and of quality
Fitting your person, to convey (with your freedome)
To th'angry King our loves, that he may see
How plain to him we mean, and how nobly
Unto a goodnesse of so fair deservings
As this now showne; see there be present order
For her Majesties attendance, and swee Coz
With-draw from the cold ayr.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Farewell Matilda;
Oh pardon me for heavens sake, now I find
Thy soul is Christall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Remember to the King
Good Madam my great sorrows; and forget not
To tell him this, that woman in whose heart
Vertue and honour stand a paire of Centinels;
The Sea may sooner flame, fire admit frost,
E're such a woman fall from heaven: Oh she,
Who as a regular star, keeps vertues speare,
Shews like a Pearl hung in an Angel eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Thou noble soul of goodnesse.

DIV1.STAGE: A Chaire of state discover'd Tables and Chaires responcible, a Guard making a lane: Enter between the, King John, Pandulph the Popes Legate, Chester Oxford, and all the Kings Party: After them, Fitzwater, Richmond, Leister, and Bruce; the King (holding the Crown) kneeling on the left side of the Chaire, Pandulph possessing it.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Lo in the sight of Prelates Peers,
Of Earth and Heaven, of all that heares
My words; I John Plantagaent,
(VVith all submissive reverence,) set
My Crowne at the most sacred foot
Of Innocent the Third, unto't
I joyne my Kingdom, giue them free
Unto his pious clemencie:
And for the follies of my Raigne,
Heats of my youth, and the rough straine
Of riper years, my Rebellions, my high hand,
My six yeares Interdictien, and
Al my mis-doings; I this, and those,
Submit to the Popes power to disclose.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: You have by times recracted, and your foot now
Beats out a certain path; in these Lords sights of I do
Produce the Letter, drawn Obligatory
From John of England to his Holinesse,
Peruse it sir, you are there oblig'd to pay,
(As yearly from this day Renting your Kingdoms)
To Innocent the Third, and to his Successors
A thousand marks per annum.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: It runnes so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Yes, three hundred for Ireland, & seven for England.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Do not peruse it John, though thou and we
Have had some bickerings, yet let me counsell thee,
This is my Countries Cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: You, and your Country
Have cause in this Cause to rejoyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Eitz.
SP.L: Good, good, Sir Pandvlph,
Though in our filiall love to our Mother Church,
By his Holinesse command, we stay'd from Hartford,
Yet lets have fair play, do not wrong that mother,
Apparelling her comely holy face,
With a forehead full of frowns, pleited proceedings.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: You raile.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: I do not raile,
Although I hold and reverence the Chair,
(We had been at Hartford else, and not at London,)
Yet in a true breast we should nothing see,
But holy pure, unmixt simplicy.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Give me the pen.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Will you then signe?

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Yes, you rough Sonnes of faction,
And hook your stubborn nostrils, this is Rubarb
To your smooth pallats: give me the pen to write.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Do not write John.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Do not prate fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: In sooth that write
Will wrong thee; Children and Fools tell truth,
Remember that.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: There was no way like this,
To beat a path out to your peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Ki.
SP.L: Right Reverend
And holy Sir, receive to the Popes use,
His will, and your own charge: Sir, descend not,
But ere you re-invest me, hear me tell
A tale of sorrow, behold here these Lords,
Who had been now bruising the face of peace
With unkind buffets, but for VVinchester,
Your strict compulsion, and their seeming fear
Of deserv'd interdiction; but oh spright,
No Devill deceives like th'houshold hypocrite,
These of my Court, with young Brace now insconc'd
At Hartford, whither it may hair brain'd Richmond
hath retir'd his discontents.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: We misse our hopes else.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: These bandy faction with me, and with their drum
(Lew'd linguists to interpret their disloyalties)
Brave me i'th field, deform th' afflicted face
Of trembling England with foul bloody stain,
Larums at hideous midnight, they break my sleeps,
Fill them with fearfull dreams, terrible startings,
And with the griefe of my unfriendly fears,
Force me to pierce my pillow with my tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Unnaturall cruellty,
Able to melt marble into compassionate tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Dainty dissembler.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: Now may it please you—

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Peace untill his holinesse command be sinished;
Ascend your now true Seat sir, and from the hand
Of my selfe Pandulph, Legate for the Pope,
Observing the due payments specified,)
Receive your Crown and Kingdoms; and with them
We here pronounce your absolute readmission
Into the Church, and from his holnesse
We re-invest you, with all Powers, Prerogatives,
Freedomes, Communities, (and in the strength of effecacy,)
That constantly adhears to lawfull Princes,
And an obedient Son unto the Church,
Long life to John of England, VVales and Ireland,
The lawfull King!

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: I am mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: So, so, now we must suffer
The Kingdoms ancient Liberties, Land, lives,
And all to run the course that he shall steere,
Good heaven that I were dead, what do I here.

SP.SPEAKER: O Bru.
SP.L: But i'le not asse-like bear my Countries wrongs,
Mine own at home, and like a Court Camelion,
Give thanks unto mine injurer: hear me King John.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: You shall hear us sir first; we have been clouded
Six years, but like the Sun in his Meridian,
We now again are glorious; thus in briefe,
Leister we require strong pledge for your loyalty;
Bruce call your mad Son home from Hartford,
Your Wife and Sonne shall better speed at Guilford,
For Richmond in our re-assumed power.
We will proclaime him Traytor, and Fitzwater,
Either give up Matilda for your faith, or heare
What we shall sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: We must stand then
What thunder you shall throw, perform with us,
We kisse your royall hands.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: If not, we stand
Rocks in our resoluton.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: D'ee heare them now sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Nay, nay, let him hear me too then:
Lord Legate Pandulph; thus 'tis,
And thus you may informe his holinesse,
In a field cal'd running-Mead' twixt Staines and VVinsor,
After some bloody noses on both sides,
I tell truth I; there the King and Barrons
Met for discussion of conceiv'd wrongs,
And indeed not misconceiv'd, our Houses, Honours,
Our Fathers freedomes, the Lands ancient Liberties
(Unjustly to encrease some private Cofers)
Felt daily Demunition, there to Covenants drawn,
(Bearing the name and sence of Magna Charta,
Which many hundred years may be seen hereafter)
King John subscrib'd, we swore him fealty.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Which fealty they deny'd, till our assoylment
Of our six years Interdiction, forcing us therefore
To seal unlawfull liberties.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Upon our honours,
They were but what Antiquity prov'd lawful.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Oh but my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Tut, tut, Lord me no Lords,
He broak, we powted, I tell plain truth I,
Yet fell into no relapse of hostility,
But wot ye what, he casts a covetous eye,
Upon my Daughter, passionately pursues her,
There had been other pledges but our oathes else,
(For heaven knows thtm he had) and (amongst the rest)
Matilda must be my pledge, for well he deem'd
They yielding their, shame would brand my denyall,
But catch craft, when we put truth to triall,
Kings should have shining souls, and white desires
Enflam'd with zeale, not parch'd by Paphian fires;
So shines the soul in which vertue doth shrowd,
Is a serene skie bespotted with no cloud,
But a Copper conscience whil'st the head wears Gold,
Is but a plain down-right untruth well told,
Come, come, I cannot fawn.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: But in the passion
Gf a Dog sir you can snarl; have you talk all your words?

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: I have told truth I.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Then we will fall to deeds,
Oxford command a Guard, and presently
Take them to'th Tower; we can now talk and do,
Away with them, and muzzel those fierce Mastiffes,
That durst leap at the face of Majestie,
And strike their killing fangs into honours heart;
Are they not gone? we shall be passionate
In your delay.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: Come Leister, let us wear
Our sufferings like Garland.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Tempest nor death,
Could never ou do Leister, who dares dye
Laughing at times poyson'd integrity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz
SP.L: Now by my troth 'twas very nobly spoken,
Shall I turne tale; no, no, no, lets go,
But how things will be carried; ha! are these teares
Body of me? they are; Shall I go like a sheep
With this pair of Lyons; ha, ha, ha,
I do laugh now John, and i'le tell thee why,
Th'art yet in thy green May, twenty seven summers
Set in our Kalends, but when forty Winters more
Shall roun'd thy forehead with a field of snow,
And when thy comely veins shall cease to flow,
When those majestick eyes shall float in rhumes,
When giant Nature her own selfe consumes,
When thy swift Pulses shall but slowly pant,
When thou art all a Volum of my want,
(That like a tale-spnt fire thou shalt snck,)
Then John upon this lesson thou wilt think
He dyes a happy old man, whose sweet youth
Was a continued sacrifice to truth;
I must weep now indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ki.
SP.L: Away with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Unto King John, the favour of his holinesse,
With peace and happinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Which we return
With all filiall obedience—look up Oxford,
The day breaks, and the Sun hath chaste the night
Out of our Hemispheare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Your news sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gen.
SP.L: Letters from the Queen sir.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Was the Earl Richmond there with any powers
E're your departure.

SP.SPEAKER: Gen.
SP.L: No may it please your Majestie, we heard not of him,
But all on your part went fair and fortunate

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Oh Oxford now they have her, flie back like lightning,
Tell him this day wee'l meet them all at Barnet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox
SP.L: But her Father and her friends imprisonment
May obdurate her heat, they dare not sure
On the great perill of a curse to fall
Into a Relapse now you are absolute.
Faith trie smooth paths to your ends, to release them,
I hold the winningst way to captivate
Their duties, and Matilda to your wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Good, do not kill me oy before our going
Instantly thou shalt flie with the Lords release,
We pine in our delayes, oh Cupid swiftly
Fly into Paphoes, and from thy Mothers shrine,
Catch but a nimble wanton flame, and cast it
Into the busie Kingdome of my heart,
That it may teach my tongue the art of victory,
And every year unto thy well-spent Quiver
I'le add a shaft, and call it Cupids love Dart;
Come Oxford, I tread methinks on aire,
Untill I read that Volum of sweet grace,
The well writ story of Matild's face.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: She yeelds at last my life on't sir.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus 3. Scoena 1.
DIV1.STAGE: Ener Brand reading of a Letter.

SP.P: WIll Brand, these are to certifie, That Fortune, Mistresses of Changes, with my unluckie stars, hathrendred m a pri∣soner to my most mortall Enemy young Bruce.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: My entreaty is none of the noblest, but direct against my blood, my desires, and my deservings.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.P: Oh that I had a leg of that young Bruce, but minc'd and butter'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I am credibly possest, his Majestie hath into your custody commited his Mother, and her young Sonne George, whereby you have occasion cast into your hand to parallel their; sufferings with my fortunes, not that I would have you banish humanity.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.P: He need never have writ that Bawds and Serjeants have sav'd me the labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Nor give to deep a wound to Conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Bran.
SP.L: Another labour sav'd too,
Usurers do it daily

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: But as I let you understand how I am here accommodated, so shape the duty of a Servant to parallel in their persons, your vil∣lified Mr Ralph Chester.

SP.SPEAKER: Bran.
SP.P: Brave Lord, the Laddar of my fortunes, suffer on that side, and for humanities sake, and thred-b conscience (a couple of cousin-Germans, that thrice a weeke know not where to get a supper;) shall the friends of him that stands Lord of thy fortunes, and thy profest foe, fare well here; now I talk of fare, I receiv'd this Letter yesterday, and since they have ueihr eaten bit, nor drunk drop, nor by these ten stealers shall not, till I heare againe from my Lord—: Come olt madam Mother, and your youg prating brat—they do look hungry already.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What would our unkind Jaylor?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Sure Mother Mr. Brand hath brought us vctuals.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: No sirrah, I come to tell you to day i fasting day.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Two dayes together,
Good Mr. Brand, 'tis not mine own want beggs,
But my poor Boyes; I have held him pretty pastime,
To have him yet forget that wild woolf hunger,
And still the harmlesse soul would point each period
Of his sport, erying Mother give me bread.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: She has a winning way,
Her carriage and her person are both exquisite:
Fai tell me Madam, what would you give for some victuals
To give your Son?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Any thing, set thou the price thou shalt have Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: And truly sir, if you'l but give me a Cake,
Or a Capons legge, when I am a man,
I'le give you twenty shillings to buy your Boy fine things.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: If you dare lye with me,
You and your Sonne shall both have sustenance.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Hearken good heaven, what saies the man?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: He would Ile with you Mother,
But then when I am a bed too, there
Will be no room for my, Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Be as plain and briefe as I was, dare yee do'?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: No thou bad man, I dare no.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: No body shall see by this hand,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Thou lyest thou feind, shouldst thou Cae do',
The Towers would tremble, and turn Intelligencers
To all the passengers; the walls would shudder,
The Ecutchions, Streamers, Baune s, all the Reliques
Of fame and honour, would fall down, to see
Honour and Fame so wounded.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: See! I am asham'd to hear you,
If such sinnes could not be done without being seen,
Informers would have a fine trade on't, a Parators place
Would counvaile five Serjeants; ha, ha, seen kither;
Why there would not be sheets en ugh in the Land
For the penitent, and innocent Beadles enough to correct the
Guilty; Come, come, we'l do't i'h dark then,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: In he dark said'st thou?
Oh in the deepest darknesse, the white Angels
Will stare upon thee, and with flaming eyes.
Will make make the room appear to thy wild conscience,
Twice lighter then the Sunne:
'Tis a foul Devil that insinuates to thee,
The sower sweetnesse of a duded minute;
He has borrowed a white robe, pluck it off from him,
And thou wilt see him a black hideous monster,
How with a slavish look he will creep from thee,
Displeas'd that thou art falne again in love,
With holy goodnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: How my Conscience wambles.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Do, do, good sir, think of it,
It will make you give's some bread.
And then you'l be a very honest man,

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: I have heard you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: And with a thirsty soul I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.P: Yes, as Usurers heare Sermons, more for novelty then integrity, I love good words when I pay nothing for ; what do you see in me that I should appear unworthy of your grant

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Because in that request,
Thou appear'st to me as ugly as a Toad.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: A Toad

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: I, and a Frog to if you go to that,
Doe not cry Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Get you both in, by this victorious sword,
And by the horrid odious comparison,
(for such a one first u e made comparisons odious)
Ye get not a bit this seven dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: By that time
My Boy and I shall make a pair of happy ones
In youder glorious Kingdom; tell me George,
Shall this bad man abnse thy Fathers bed?
Or shall we fast yet longer?

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: The boy will consent I warrant you,
The Pages have instructed him.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Indeed I am very hungry:

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Did I not tell you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: But rather then this Goat shall lie in my fathers place,
Indeed 'le fast this seven years.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Ah noble boy,
Sweet plant of goodnesse, thou hast prov'd it true,
Vertue will wish the good it cannot do.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Aterribly ugly Toad.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Good sir ye must be patient.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Patient,
Bitternesse dwels with me: if I do not put him
To an eternall patience, that shall dare
To witch me into that dull fit of fools;
Matilda won and lost

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Good sir

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Away;
Struggle not with the tempest of my blood,
That will undo the.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Richmond Lyon like,
(After we sent our Letter with the Foree
The Barrous had prepar'd,) clouded our day,
And made our fortunes his.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: They out o'th Tower to,
Fitzwater Bruce, and Leister, with fresh powers,
Are not a league hence.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: The Lyon Richmond, a Hare had he met with any
But field Mice, Rats, Run-awayes, and Weezles,
Frighted even with the waving of a Flag,
They would have call'd scar-crow stufi'd with straw,
And bound upon a ten groats Irish Garron,
The Glorious Richmond pon his firie Steed;
Oh there is nothing certaine but our sorrows,
Our borrow'd blisse is but the shuttl-cock
Of a dayes pastime.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: I have pastim'd her, if tearing be a pastime,
Let that comfort you,
I have torne her almost to d: ath.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Matilda.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: And would you have it comfort me?

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: I know it does, call but up your Troops
Brayely again, recover her, and read
Upon her face my fury.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Oh ye cruell one,
Crueller then the flame that turn'd to Clnders
The fair Ephesian Temple; wilde as a Woolf,
The Bear is not so bloody, teare her hairs,
Which when they took their astime with the winds,
Would charm the astonish'd gazer; tear that face,
Lovely as is the morning in whose eyes
Stands writ the history of her heart, intioing
The ravish'd Reader to runne on, 'pon whose eye lids
Discretion dwels, which when a wilde thought
Would at those Casements like a Theefe steale in,
Playes her heart's noble friend, and shuts out sin.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: O why then sir, if she be such a volum
Of white unvanquish'd would you stain.
And blot the sair leaves with your desir
Ghaste, frostie bosomes, brook no lust-born fires.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: She has put me to my sophistry.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: I knew I was made
Your staie for her obtaining.
Oh why
Raise you so high a Piramis to her praise,
And prostrate your own vertue? if she be
Such a Book of goodnesse (with bad desires)
Why do you read her? He no truth intends,
Seeks to corrupt that Text which he commends,
Good sir consider it.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Well, I will think on', and you will have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Now is the time my Lord,
If e're you would be fortunate in your desires,
Richmond, young Bruce, Matilda,
(With the Earl of Chester prisoner,) and a slight convoy
But of some threescore Horse, and two hundred Archer
Are now i'th valley crossing of the County,
'Tis thought for Essex.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Where are their main Forces?

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Inscon'st in Hartford Castle, our Forces yet
Not so diminish'd, or in rout for want
Of their lost Generall, but if you please,
We dare with hope assail them.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: I will be Generall,
Order the Powers you have for present on-set.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: My Lord, you said you would consider.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: I am considering bravely how to charge
The Foe just in the face: Matilda I am now thy Souldier,
Friend of my heart, the King himselfe comes for thee,
Who shall in this dayes doings amply prove,
Honour takes fire from the flame of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Good fortune on our side sir.

DIV1.STAGE: Exeunt. Manet Queen. A Charge afar off.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Hear not that prayer
Good heaven, oh tempt not vertue to adorn
A foul Cause with fair fortunes: Hark, hark, they meet,
And now pell mell the angry Lords do list
Unnaturall swords, good heaven keep safe the King,
But let his Cause miscarry; I w ll not stay
To see him so pursue those wild desires,
Which cannot sure end well; i'le to the Lords
So near at hand, and with Matilda's Father,
Accommodate my griefs, and let there be
Her feares, my tears, the Kings infirmity.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Oxford, sh's now the Kings.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Most miserable Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Most excellent Matilda all are thy friends,
Imperious love fat on my lance just then,
When on the paning brest of daring Richmond.
(Who like a meancholly sullen Cloud,
Eclips'd thy Chariot) thou didst see me print
My relesse passion: Oxford keep my happinesse,
Just with that care thou wouldst oreserve that pair
Of prc ous things, thine eye; Chesters ingag'd
Deep in the Chae, and we must tech him off;
Pardon me honour that I placd love first,
My doings now are thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Keep near the King, Gentlemen,
His unbounded spirit may loose him ele; good Madam
Do not lament so, though your friends are catter'd,
Y'are in a spheare of happinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh that great power,
That many times out of this toy I hath taken me,
Deliver me again, because again,
Vertue hath made me miserabl.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Oh that necessity
Should force us unto flight, base flight, repugnant
To man and honour. Ha! nappy flight now,
That brought me this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Cozen.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Oxford, either give back
That pure unspotted Dove, from the killing Tallon
Of the forgetfull King, or thou or I
Must never see him more.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: That to our fortunes,
I must not faile the King sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: I must not faile then
To get her as I can sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: We are scatter'd now
Paste making head againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: But I have made shift to get my Cuz agen sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Let us not stay now to expostulate, Necessity
Directs us to our friends not a league distant,
If we not fly we are lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Good Cuz lets flie,
Tis no difgrace to obey necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Oh I could stamp and tear that hagge necessity,
Bitter necessity, thou scourge of things
That forces Lyons to wear Swallows wings.

DIV1.STAGE: Exe. Manet Ox. to him enter King, Chester, & others.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: You have plaid the Souldier sir.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: The Souldier Chester; I am so light with joy,
I could do any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Troth sir would it might please you then to grace
Me with the President-ship of Picardy,
Falne in this last Rebellion from the Lord
Bruce uno your Crown.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Tis thine as certaine
As Matilda is the Kings: Oh Chester, now Matilda
Is in the Kings power.

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: No sir, she is in heavens.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Who's this, Oxford, lets help to raise him up.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: What saist thou man? Matilda, where is Matilda?

SP.SPEAKER: Ox.
SP.L: Young Bruce in his flight happening upon this way
For her recovery gave me fierce assault;
I did stand for you sir as much as man could,
Till my mis-fortune found me, then I fell;
To him eame Richmond, and with all speed possible
They have carried her to'th Lords on tother side the hath.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Oh villaine, villaine
Suppose he had cut thy hear strings, hadst thou cast
Thy dying eye upon Matilda's face?
She would have shot another spirit into thee,
More daring then the first, at least more fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Let him be convey'd to'ch Town and drest,
Our best course is now to with-draw, the Lords
Are strong, and may give us dangerous chase else.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: What are our hopes
Like Garlands, pon afflictions forehead worn,
Kist in the morning, and at evening torne.

DIV1.STAGE: Exit. A Table and Chaires set out.
Enter Fitzwater, Old Bruce, young Bruce, Richmond, and Leister.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: The day is then the Kings.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: White victory
Clapt on her silver wings, with a sullen face,
Took leave of us, and pitched upon his Tent,
Where she sat smiling, while necessity.
Enforced our flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Oh that witch Necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Well, well, away with the witch,
Tis well you brought Matilda off; come, come,
Aud brther Bruce you have a Wife and Sonne
Unjustly detayn'd from you, I am injur'd,
I pray set you our feet into the path
Of our proceedings.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Lets with our powers
Raze Winsor walls.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Now you are i'th field straight,
Give old men leave; you would raze! what would you raze
Your reputation with your rash proceedings;
Come, come, hear your Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Why let him speak them,

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: First let us take up our affronts in order,
And fix by ours, the Generalls grievances,
The crying groans of England, whose blubberd cheeks
Are stiffe with tears, to see their privildedges
Daily impair'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: What's to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Let's send to the French King,
Proffer him our assistance, to trans-fer
The Crown from John to him, if at such a day
He will put over a strong Navie Royall,
With an Army for the attempt, with which (our Forces
Making one body) both at at Sea and Land,
We bid fair for our freedoms.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: I do not like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Eru.
SP.L: S'foot, you will like nothing;
Let us be ring'd and nooz'd,

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: Besides, being assoil'd of his six years Interdiction,
Those that before fled from him as a Leaper,
Will now flock to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: They begin already,
(Although we seek (with our own) their good,) to censure
And call hostility plain faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: This is my resolve, I say there is no way
To fix our freedomes, but to call in Philip
And make him King.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.L: So think we all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: I but I think not so,
Though y'are all wise for Philip, he'l be a gainer,
But what will you get by't? They run on Rocks and shelves,
Can can counsell others, not secure themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: We must and will do something.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: You will send to Philip,
Instruct him to proceed, it may be furnish
His Navie with our Pilots, he lands, we proffer
Change, John for Philip; oh can you think,
That we can undergo a heavier stroke
From a Naturall, then from a Forreigne yoak;
Go to, go to, who in no estate can rest,
They may change oft, but seldome comes the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: I am diverted.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: Which way would you steer then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: By the same Compasse, but not upon this parallel,
I do not like the line; but this wee'l do,
Wee'l send for Lewis, Philips Sonne the Dolphine,
And to him (seemingly) preter the proffer,
A Crown will fire him; may be he shall land,
But with no more Force then we please; and it may be
He shall take a fisher Town, for every Nation
Can take away their trading as the time goes,
Our mine Force being ready, we will hover
'Twixt John and Lewis; if John deny an oath
To redresse our griefes, and become regular
And Hostage for the keeping it, we joyne
With the French and fright him further; If he consent,
We fall on his part then, expulse Lewis,
And send him to the Seas again; the Dolphine
Is young and may be wrought on, but old Philip
Is dangerously politick, with foot ashore,
Hee'l brook no jugling, both ease, and safety
We work on Willowes, but when we strike at Oaks,
We sweat, and sometimes hurt with our own strokes.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.L: It shall be thus effected.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: But let report divulge his Landing,
With more eminent danger then we will let him practise.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: For this time
Rise then; See the Queen and Ladies,
Good Madam cast off sadnesse,
Matilda we are all here i'th City safe;
The very hearts o'th Citizens (men injur'd
In their priviledges as we are) they are ours,
What should we fear then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You are all such friends,
I am poor in my well-meaning thankfuln̄esse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: A Barge with divers youthfull Citizens,
Apparell'd rich like Masquers, is now land'd
Upon the Stairs, hearing the Queen was here,
ithall this meeting of their noble friends,
Proffer their loves and duties to conclude
And grace the evening with their Revels.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: In the Hall wee'l meet them. Did not I tell you
These Citizens were noble lads our friends?
Waite on the Ladies Lords, I am here your Graces servant,
By my troth I thank'em, they will crown our feast,
And credite me, having such a princely guest.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter at one doore Fitzwater, old Bruce, young Bruce, Leister, Matilda and Ladies; at the other doore, the King, Chester, Oxford, Masquers.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Now by my troth they are gallants,
Citizens said you; now I remember to,
Ye do go gallant in your Shops, no wonder then,
If in Masques you cut it. I remember Gentlemen,
Your Fathers wore a king of comely habite,
Comely, because it wel became the reverend name of Citizens,
But now let a Knight walk with you in your shops,
(And I commend you for't, ye keep the fashion)
We know not which is which—; how my tongue ranges,
And night grows old, mad times, must have mad changes;
Come, come, a Hall, a hall.

DIV1.STAGE: The Masquers take the Ladies, and fall to the Dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Beleeve me you have done well.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Pox a' these Cats guts, how they squeak.
Methinks a rattling sheep-skin lustily boxt,
Would thunder brave amongst them.

DIV1.STAGE: One of the Torch bearers takes Matilda.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I can dance no more indeed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: I am deceiv'd if that fellow did not carry
A Torch e'n now;
Will you shame the Gentleman?
Dance when I bid you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh me, that graspe was like the Kings.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bru.
SP.L: Dance Cuz.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: In good deed dance,
Or you will make me angry.
Body of me, that's too much for a Torch-bearer,
You sir Jack, sir Jack, she is no whit-leather,
She will not stretch I assure you, if you come hither
For love so 'tis.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: For love.

SP.SPEAKER: Eitz.
SP.L: But if you and your Company,
Put on forgetfull rudenesse, pray take your Cupid yonder,
Your thing of feathers, and your Barge stands ready
To bear ye all aboard the ship of Fools,
I am plain Robin—passion of me!
Look if he do not threaten me; I will see thee,
Wert thou King John himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.L: The King!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh which way shall I flie?

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: I would not leave so sweet a chaste companion.

DIV1.STAGE: Exeunt Qu. Mat. Rich, and Ladies. In the bussle, Fitzwater drops one of his Gloves, Hubert takes it up, and goes after the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: What's this, one of her Fathers Gloves?
This shall be drawn upon the luckie hand of a thriving plot.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Behold thy King, thine Bruce, one of the Fathers
Of these retir'd factions; Richmond, the King,
And thine ough Leister; is this still your nest
Wherein to hatch another Scorpions Egge,
To sting the afflicted bosome of your Country,
To bruise her sides with the earth-wounding hoofes
Of War-apparell'd Horses, whose dreadful neighings
May fright her pale face to a bloody blush,
And again make her groane.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Your pardon sir,
By my good Sword I knew ye not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: No, if you had,
Your dangerous Brother Bruce and you, had laid
Some plot for his sacred person; then pleaded ignorance,
That ye took him as he seem'd, a sawcy stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Chester, Thou art not noble in thy cnsure,
And sawn 'st thy selfe into the abus'd favour
Of the to-credulous King.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Oh temptation, what a Devill art thou;
Now by my blood young man, you court my spleen
In a vain glorious shape; Chester fawne,
Just heaven forbid it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: An Axe upon your neck, che just heavens give you
And that in heaven were justice—

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: Sonne, y'are too full of choller.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Choller, Halter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: By the masse that's neer the choller.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Upon your lives no more, the King is here;
Fitzwater, I did not come to quarrell with thee,
I would have such a good man ever neer me,
And for a florish to the rest (of whom
As of old Bruce we have) we will require strict pledges, and
Fitzwater let thy Daughter live at Court, she shall be kept.
I'th custody of the Queen, but as no pledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: The Queen is gracioue.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Come, to their ruines leave these turbulent Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: But suppose the Queen should ride abroad to hunt,
And leave Matilda solitary at home,
I think the King would come and comfort her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ki.
SP.L: I am of thy mind, I think he would.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Would he so?— I would have no one hear.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: They cannot man.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Pray tell the King, ile keep my Girle at home,
And comfort her my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: You will.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: John, John, now I speak out;
You made your Masque for this, a Masque indeed,
And we-aday! that it should prove a Cover
For such a night of Tempests, such wilde affections,
Such an ill-favour'd night.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Hubert, is't done?

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Past expectation, I have better'd your plot,
And got the Queene too,
And will bring them early in the morning to'th Court.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Have the Torch-bearers given fire to the plot?

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: They mixt with oppertunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: I do not like this whispering,
Where are the Ladies and Matilda?

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: The Ladies are at the further side the Castle,
But by a Glove you sent by a Gentleman,
That said he serv'd Earle Leister, that with him
She and the Queene should flie for safety whither
You had directed him, glad of any scare,
They took a Barge, another leapt in after them,
But whom he was I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. Bru.
SP.L: Sent you a Glove.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: A Glove indeed I misse, but I sent none.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: This is a Riddle.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: I will play Oedipus, and expound it for you,
As Hubert has infus'd; you drop'd your Glove,
Ingenius Hubert found it, and (though we
Had directed otherwise,) he employ'd a Gentleman
Of our own Chamber, one unknown to Matilda,
To bring it as your close intellige ce
For her flight with him; he that leapt into 'th Barge,
As they put of, was Oxford, now we have her
Never again to lose her.

SP.SPEAKER: Leis.
SP.L: By my vext blood
King John, this is not honourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: We are betray'd,
All that bore Torches in the Masque to night,
Were of the Guard, who upon a receiv'd watch-word,
Fell to their Arms, beat down all oppos'd them,
And are shaping their course this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bru.
SP.L: Lets meet'em,
We have an injur'd patience, came death in whirle-winds,
Ile be the first shall front him; to thy prayers John,
Pray heartily, that thy friends fatall points
May pierce these hearts; for if they misse 'tshall prove
The bloodi st beauty story ever told
To fright the Readers souls; a purple cloud
Shall shaddow England, the whole Land shall ele,
The Center gras, thy very Crown shall stand
Trembling upon thy Temples, till it fall
A Mourner at thy fames black funerall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Oh noble Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, let 'em rave on; Ingenious Hubert
That couldst so swifty apprehend a smooth
Path to'th possession of Matilda!
Quit Oxford from her charge; unto thy care
The King commends the Mistresse of his heart,
I'th morning let me see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: She shall waite upon you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: The Barrons threaten high sir.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Let them burst.
Come Gentlemen, to'th Barge, and so to'th Court,
To clip our wishes, perills appear sport.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus 4. Scoena 1.

SP.SPEAKER: Bran.
SP.L: I Wonder how my pair of Prisoners fadge?
I am something dogged too a to'ther side,
That thus long have not seen them, nor have they eate
I am sure since they came in; in yon Madams eye
I am as ugly as a Toad, I will see her,
And contemn her—, you and your brat come out,
Heres meat, I am sure you are hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: O Mother, will you be sick now?
Mr. Boand hath brought us meat.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Oh on my knee sir
I thank you, not for my want, for I feel
Nature almost quite vanquish'd; but for my Sonne;
He may live long to thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Give but my Mother
A little piece of bread, and if I live,
(as yet I may do, if you can be mercifull)
I will tell my Father such good things of you,
He shall return your kindnesse treble back
To your honest bosome; Oh Mother for some bread.

SP.SPEAKER: Era.
SP.L: Some bread?
Why to have an honest bosome (as the world goes)
Is the next way to want bread; i faith tell me,
How have you past the time you wanted Victul?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Very hardly,
And still the poor Boy sighin, would say, Mother
You look very hungry, I did think straight how had
Your heart was, then we both did fall a weeping,
Cling'd our lean armes about each others neck,
And sat a pair of mouers.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Delicate pastime, Toads love no other;
Look yee, here is bread.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Oh if you be a good man, give me but a bit
To give my Mother, poor soul look how she looks!
Indeed she's very hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Yes, so is my Dogge,
I must keep this for his breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Give but my boy one bi,
And the Saints sure will look how good you are,
They will be glad to see you charitable,
And call it excellent compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: No, cunning from a Toad 'twill pyson him.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: It will not sir, indeed I am so hungry,
I could eat Rats or Mice.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Your to'ther hair braine,
Your wilde mad Sonne, retaines my Lord a Prisoner,
Uses him basely, and you must suffer for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Give me but Paper, Pen and Inck, i'le wrile,
And charge him to fall down, and lik the dust.
Thy Lord shall set his foot on, I will conjure him:
And woe away his wildnesse by the groars
I sufer'd for him, I'le threaten his denyall
With a Mothers family-consounding curse:
This I will do, or any thing that may
But purchase my poor Boy one bit of bread.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O harder then the Rocks, more mercilesse
Then the wilde evening Woolf.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Mother do not die,
For heavens sake helpe my Mother; look up
And ye shall see me dance, and then the Gentleman
Will sure bestow a piece of bread upon us.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Look here thou Iron-hearted man. upon
A palre of piercing miseries.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: A Scoene of mirth;
I am all hard, the heat of lust which stood
To clip revenge, we stem a stream of blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: How do ye Mother?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: How doth my Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Very sick indeed; but I warrant you are more hungry
Then I a great deale, are you not?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Oh no,
Thou art weake, and famine plaies the Tyrant with thee;
Look here my boy, bite on thy Mothers arme,
The blood will nourish thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Will your blood nourish me?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Yes, yes, I prehee try.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Why should not mine then nourish you? 'tis the same;
Good Mother eat my arme, bite but a bite,
Truly I shall hurt you if I bite yours,
I warrant you'l be better presently.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I shall my Sonne, and so shalt thou, come neere me,
Let us go hand in hand to Heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Oh mother, something pinch'd my very heart,
And I shall die, my dear, dear mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Art thou gone my Sonne?
My soule shall overtake thee: oh friendly death
That gav'st that gripe, sure when thou kill'st the guilty,
Frowns curle thy angry forehead; but when thou steal'st
Towards innocence, (their pale fears to beguile)
Thou deck'st thy lean face with a lovely smile.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: My Lord recover'd by the valiant King!
In all his battels he is fortunate,
And now tdey shall have meate; ha! meat said I?
I have made them worms meat;
Oh what a talking is within me! if I stay,
The building sure will crush me, i'le ha to'h Court,
My Lord here intimates the Kings observance of me,
I must hence; oh gnilt, thou draw'st deaths image horrid,
When we begin to like our ills, how sweet a face hath sin!
Which but past by, a cheater she appears,
Joyes are her promise, but she paies us fears.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Hubert, Queen, and Matilda, a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Your care in the conveyance of Matilda
To this appoited place, the King shall recompence,
With-draw your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: I shall my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Matilda, where's that spirit that kept thy vertue
Valiant and bold

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: If vertue so ill pay us,
Who would be vertuous?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Vertue! pale poverty
Reproach, disaster, shame sits on her forehead,
Despisings fill her sleep, ill
Meet her at every turne, tears are her triumphs,
Her drink affliction, Calumny attends her,
The unclean tongue of slaunder daily licks her
Out of her fashion; but if you be Kings Johns friend—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh strong temptation.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Matilda—

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: You may like
A nimble wind, play on the ruslling bosome
Of that phantastick wood, the world; your sleeps a paradice
hung round with glittering dreames, then your dissemblings
call'd devtions, your rigged hypocrisie
Religions holy heats, mirth dee the Court dis,
The wanton minutes glide just like a streame,
That clips the bosome of a wealthy meade,
Till't get it great with child, a sweet green blassing.
Consider, 'tis the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: I, I, the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Trust not this tempter, lusts irreligious linguist,
Remember vertue is a holy flame,
A sacred inclination of the soul
To all things honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I can resist no longer,
Oh Hubert, you are a victorious tempter.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Can this be possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Forget not, at the beginning
Of this sweet race, honour hold out for you
A golden Garland.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Oh remember,
At the end of chastities white race, an Angell
Holds in his hand (shot through a silver Cloud,)
A Crown for Conquerers.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub
SP.L: Will ye loose the pleasure that—

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: I, I, those pleasures Hubert, there is a voyce
Of flesh and frailty in me, that still cryes,
Matilda take those pleasures, and I am now
The Kings for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Let the Queen then cut from earth
Such a dissembler.

DIV1.STAGE: Offers violence to Matil. Hubert stayes her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Nay but you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Shame and death dwell
With a goodnesse so short-si'd, thou hansome hypocrite,
Thou faith-defrauder, a religious qualme
Crossing the stomack of a seeming Saint,
Which falls straight into humoor, all thy devotions
Prove now but well-clad cheaters of Times Charity,
Thy griefs, and sighs, are but sins crafty games,
Their soon spnt flashes play like holy flames.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: It shall be so: to some remote place, shut
from the danger of the angry Queen i'le carry you,
And thither bring the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I long to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Hubert, wilt thou play the Court Camclion,
The persum'd Pander.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Yes marry will I, Panders have need of perfumes.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Oh merry sinne!
We smile towards Hell, but howl when we are in,

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Name but the place Madam, and religiously I vow,
By th'unstain'd honour of my Name and Houe,
By the white reputation of a Gentleman,
And as I wish for after happinesse, my care
Shal I see it instantly in execution.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: My Cousen Bruce, Earl Richmond, with the convoy,
The King discomfited, they would madly have carried me
To Dunmow Abbey in fruitfull Essex.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Soot a thousand Kings
could not thence recover ye, but name the place
Whither I shall carry you, good Madam whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Good Hubert thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: What to a Monastory?

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Call her dissembling,
No nne good heaven, for she is still a Saint.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Upon my knee I begge it, and every day
When I shall drop a Bead, I'le strongly pray
That you may find a blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Hark Hubert.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: There is something telis me there is honour in it,
To grant her good request.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Mark how your Oath ran,
By the honour of your House,
By the white reputation of a Gentleman.
And as you wish for after happinesse.
You'd put my wish in speedy execution.
Oh Hubert mark, he his house pulls down,
That wounds his honour, though to please a Crown,
By Heraul'ds he's a Gentleman maintain'd,
Whose reputations whitenesse stands unstain'd,
And he in after happinesse stands high,
That dares not with a sinne by soveraignty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: Excellent Oratory!

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: Hubert, for truths sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh Hubert, for the glorious Crown of chastity,

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: For the victorious Palme of Wedlock faith,

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: By the immaculate souls of holy Maids,

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: And by the unstain'd truth of honest wives,

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: By the tears of Virgins,

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.L: By the truth of vertue,

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh now to honour Hubert give thy name,
Sweet blooming vertue knows no blush of shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Hub.
SP.L: The rarenesse of your souls has ravish'd me,
Wee'l change our course, steere through bridge, and so
For Essex and for Dunmow, victorious Maid,
Rhetorick is poor in thy praise, whom a King,
Nor soveraignty, (the soul of womens longings,)
Cannot corrupt!—Oh women! Men-subduers!
Natures extreames! no meane is to be had;
Excellent Good, or infinitely bad!

SP.SPEAKER: Ambo.
SP.L: Most noble Hubert.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter King, Fitzwater, Chester and Oxford.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: 'Twas well yet that the trick has catch'd this old one,
Where are the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Ches.
SP.L: Richmond is gone for France,
Leister escap'd to Winsor.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: How I thirst
To make mine arms walthy with sweet Matilda.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz.
SP.L: Oh if a Fathers prayers, an old mans tears,
An injur'd old mans tears, were ever prevalent,
Good heaven keep my Girle a Christall Fort,
Firme and unvuanquish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: Hnbert my friend now has her:
Will it please the mighty Emporor of the Barrons,
The King may kisse Matilda, she will be here presently,
Then shall the great Fitzwater sit in state,
And see Matilda and the poor King dallie,
And teach the winds to wanton; Hubert now has her,
The faithful'st of my friends, from contrarities
We will produce soft pleasures, sweet perfections;
Sirah, Chester shall tell me when she then frowns, and
